title: American_Top_40_1982_December_4th
description:
"From Hollywood, this is Casey Kasem, and the countdown doesn't stop till we get to number one."


American Top 40 with Casey Kasem aired on radio from July 4, 1970 until August 6, 1988. This is a recording of a rebroadcast from internet radio.

In this broadcast:

Casey tells how the Bee Gees gave away what might have been a number one song so another band could have a hit single.

"Baby, Come To Me" by Patti Austin & James Ingram was on the hot 100 once before earlier in the year. It never made it into the top 40. But after it was featured on General Hospital it came back on the chart and is now at number 31.

A listener wants to know, "What recording act charting in the rock era has had the longest name?" Casey says this band of fighting men wore kilts and had a hit with a Christian hymn.

Casey recounts the story of how Lou Rawls was once in a terrible car accident and suffered from total amnesia.

There is a duet in this countdown by two artists who - between them - have appeared on 35 number one records. That breaks a record set just 6 months earlier by Stevie Wonder and Paul McCartney.

LW#3: Heart Attack - Olivia Newton-John
LW#2: Gloria - Laura Brannigan
LW#1: Truly - Lionel Richie
